awd_titl_txt: Improving Discovery Prospects and Measurement Precision for New Physics at the Large Hadron Collider
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Can Kilic at the University of Texas at Austin.  

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) has been operational since 2010, probing nature at shorter distance scales than any previous collider experiment. In 2012 the LHC has led to the discovery of the Higgs boson, the only particle in the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics that had not been observed previously. After this final triumph of the SM, the primary mission of the LHC will be to look for new physics beyond the SM. The existence of such new physics within the reach of the LHC is motivated by several observations which cannot be explained within the SM, but which point to the distance scales that are being explored at the LHC. The existence of Dark Matter (DM) in the universe with the correct properties is an example of this. In light of the fact that no clear signs of such new physics have been observed so far, the possibility needs to be considered that the new particles in question may be difficult to discover, either because they are rarely produced, or because their experimental signatures can be easily mistaken for those of known particles present in the SM. The results of the LHC searches for new physics will define the path of high energy physics in the future, which makes it essential that all efforts be made to maximize the discovery potential.  Professor Kilic's research project will address how further optimization for discovery and higher precision for measurements can be obtained in the challenging scenarios mentioned above. 

There are also several broader impacts of the research described in this project. A significant portion of the research will be conducted by graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, which will allow them to develop critical research skills in pursuing an academic career path. In order to make it possible for young people to appreciate the excitement associated with particle physics, Professor Kilic will also give lectures about aspects of modern physics at local high schools including the Liberal Arts and Science Academy (LASA) and Travis High School.  At a more formal level, Professor Kilic also teaches a class on the SM and on beyond-the-SM physics at the University of Texas at Austin at the postgraduate level, the curriculum of which will be modified in light of future discoveries made at the LHC.

During the grant period, Kilic, postdoc Yu and graduate students Klimek, Swaminathan, Trendafilova and Yang have conducted research on a range of topics in particle physics including dark matter, collider physics and model building.

Despite its phenomenal successes, the Standard Model of particle physics does not provide a complete description of microscopic physics. It is for instance known that the majority of the matter content of the universe is made up of dark matter. While matter in the form of atoms and molecules consists of particles described by the Standard Model, dark matter represents a new type of particle. Kilic worked on many aspects of dark matter physics, most recently on the scenario of Flavored Dark Matter. Standard Model particles exist in groups of multiple copies, called flavors, for reasons that are currently not known. Even though dark matter is often assumed to be a single particle for simplicity, it is important to explore whether a similar flavor structure may exist for dark matter, and how such flavored dark matter can be experimentally distinguished from single-flavor dark matter. This possibility exhibits many interesting theoretical and experimental challenges, and has become an active area of research since the original study by Kilic and collaborators. During the grant period, Kilic explored in a number of papers the signatures of flavored dark matter at the Large Hadron Collider and in dark matter searches, as well as a novel mechanism by which the dark matter abundance today may have been generated in the early universe.

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is producing particle collisions at higher energies than ever before and thus represents one of our best chances for looking for physics beyond the Standard Model. In many hypothetical extensions of the Standard Model, particles produced at the LHC will undergo cascade decays until a stable particle is reached. Kilic has studied a method for improving the precision in measuring the masses of particles in such cascade decays. This method relies on taking advantage of correlations in the kinematics of these events and it has been shown to outperform the most common methods especially when only a modest number of events are available to study.

In 2015, the LHC experiments ATLAS and CMS have identified an excess of events with two photons that may in fact be the first hint of a new particle. While this finding needs to be confirmed with data taken in 2016, Kilic studied possible extensions of the Standard Model that could explain this excess. In particular, the scenario of a new strong interaction with new particles that respect parity, which Kilic worked on in the past, was shown to be a viable explanation. Kilic identified predictions that can be used to confirm or rule out this scenario.

Yu and collaborators also worked on collider physics, in particular on the details of single production of top quarks, and on the pair production of the W, Z and Higgs bosons.

In the context of model building, Kilic and Yu worked on a number of theoretical questions on physics beyond the Standard Model. Kilic and Swaminathan explored the features of electroweak symmetry breaking in theories where Standard Model particles are paired with new particles that have the same spin. Yu and collaborators studied properties of the Higgs sector when new parity-respecting matter particles are added to the Standard model, as well as how this sector could provide the connection between dark matter and the Standard Model.
